name: Aaron Davis
note: I am an Australian educator supporting schools with the integration of technology and pedagogical innovation. I have an interest in how together we can work to make a better world.

summary.html:
North Americans tend to assume the Pan-American Highway was completed, that you can drive from North America down through the narrowing isthmus of Central America into South America. Try it, though, and you‚Äôll dead-end in Panama.

A map of the Darien Gap via Wikimedia Commons
The border between Panama and Columbia is where the dream faltered. A route through El Tap√≥n Dari√©n, the Dari√©n Gap, was never cleared and paved. To this day, writes Miller, ‚ÄúPanama and Colombia are the only neighboring nations on the globe without a single road link of even the most primitive kind.‚Äù

content.html: Matthew Wills discusses the history of the Pan-American Highway and inability to mark a path through the Dari√©n Gap. For more on the Dari√©n Gap, Jason Motlagh documents his experience of passing through the region.

name: Five thoughtful ways to approach artificial intelligence in schools

summary.html: The use of artificial intelligence in schools is the best example we have right now of what we call a sociotechnical controversy. As a result f of political interest in using policy and assessment to steer the work that is being done in schools, partly due to technological advances and partly due to‚Ä¶
summary.value: The use of artificial intelligence in schools is the best example we have right now of what we call a sociotechnical controversy. As a result f of political interest in using policy and assessment to steer the work that is being done in schools, partly due to technological advances and partly due to‚Ä¶

content.html:
Greg Thompson, Kalervo Gulson and Teresa Swist provide five recommendations when considering the use of artificial intelligence in schools:

Ultimately, we suggested five key recommendations.

  1. Time and resources have to be devoted to helping professionals understand, and scrutinise, the AI tools being used in their context.¬†
  2. There needs to be equity in infrastructure and institutional resourcing to enable all institutions the opportunity to engage with the AI tools they see as necessary. We cannot expect individual schools and teachers to overcome inequitable infrastructure such as funding, availability of internet and access to computational hardware.¬†
  3. Systems that are thinking of using AI tools in schools must prioritise Professional Learning opportunities well in advance of the rollout of any AI tools. This should be not be on top of an already time-poor¬†
  4. Opportunities need to be created to enable all stakeholders to participate in decision-making regarding AI in schools. It should never be something that is done to schools, but rather supports the work they are doing.
  5. Policy frameworks and communities need to be created that guide how to procure AI tools, when to use AI, how to use AI why schools might choose not to use AI in particular circumstances.¬†
@AustAssocResEd https://www.aare.edu.au/blog/?p=14976
content.value:

Ultimately, we suggested five key recommendations.

Time and resources have to be devoted to helping professionals understand, and scrutinise, the AI tools being used in their context.¬†
There needs to be equity in infrastructure and institutional resourcing to enable all institutions the opportunity to engage with the AI tools they see as necessary. We cannot expect individual schools and teachers to overcome inequitable infrastructure such as funding, availability of internet and access to computational hardware.¬†
Systems that are thinking of using AI tools in schools must prioritise Professional Learning opportunities well in advance of the rollout of any AI tools. This should be not be on top of an already time-poor¬†
Opportunities need to be created to enable all stakeholders to participate in decision-making regarding AI in schools. It should never be something that is done to schools, but rather supports the work they are doing.
Policy frameworks and communities need to be created that guide how to procure AI tools, when to use AI, how to use AI why schools might choose not to use AI in particular circumstances.¬†

summary.html: But definitely, something is going on that has temporarily shut down our ability to access a sense of the timeless in order to construct stable notions of ourselves in relation to it. For the time being, we seem to be eternity blind, unable to see past the sound and fury of reboots and reruns of our collective memories.

summary.html: Not all of our lingo can or should be replaced with simpler words. Nor would everyone who criticizes it be satisfied with greater clarity. Nevertheless, educators, like other professionals, have a responsibility to communicate as clearly as possible with people outside their field. It‚Äôs a matter of basic courtesy to elucidate terms that may be puzzling to others even though we‚Äôve come to take them for granted. And that clarity may also help more people to understand why traditional practices so often fall short and thus to build a constituency for change.

name: What if the world‚Äôs best-selling books are actually misleading?
The Man Behind Mastodon, Eugen Rochko, Built It for This Moment

summary.html: People fleeing Twitter have turned to Eugen Rochko‚Äôs alternative. He says social networks can support healthy debate‚Äîwithout any one person in control.
summary.value: People fleeing Twitter have turned to Eugen Rochko‚Äôs alternative. He says social networks can support healthy debate‚Äîwithout any one person in control.

content.html:
In an interview with Will Knight, Eugen Rochko discusses the current move to Mastodon, Musk‚Äôs free publicity and the differences with Twitter. Rochko also explains why the same thing that has happened with Twitter cannot happen with Mastodon.

What if someone‚Äîsay an impulsive billionaire‚Äîwanted to buy Mastodon or take control of it somehow?

The network is protected from something like that. The code is free, open-source software, and nobody can change the license or take it back retroactively, and all of the different servers are owned by other people. Somebody could buy Mastodon gGmbH [the German nonprofit that maintains the software] and with it the trademark and the servers we run‚Äîmastodon.social and mastodon.online‚Äîbut it wouldn‚Äôt affect the Fediverse in any significant way.

Eugen Rochko https://www.wired.com/story/the-man-behind-mastodon-eugen-rochko-built-it-for-this-moment/

In other pieces on Mastodon, Clive Thompson suggests that it is an example antiviral design that encourages murmuring conversations, rather than the must-see post.

And I‚Äôve realized that Mastodon is a superb example of antiviral design.

It was engineered specifically to create friction ‚Äî to slow things down a bit. This is a big part of why it behaves so differently from mainstream social networks.

https://uxdesign.cc/mastodon-is-antiviral-design-42f090ab8d51

Jeremy Keith compares the exodus from Twitter to being at Dunkirk.

Right now, Twitter feels like Dunkirk beach in May 1940. And look, here comes a plucky armada of web servers running Mastodon instances!

Jeremy Keith https://adactio.com/journal/19650

Wouter Groeneveld wonders if social media scrolling is the answer, something I have been wondering about for a while.

I don‚Äôt really know what I‚Äôm trying to say here except that it‚Äôs perhaps not worth it to scroll endlessly on yet another social media platform where posts are starting to converge into the emptiness that Twitter had to offer.

Wouter Groeneveld https://brainbaking.com/post/2022/11/the-great-mastodon-influx/

Jim Groom and the team at Reclaim Hosting have documented how to setup your own instance.
content.value:

content.html:
Tom Critchlow talks about going beyond the right answer to instead positing the ‚Äònext most useful thing‚Äô.

I‚Äôve been using this phrase ‚Äúthe next most useful thing‚Äù as a guiding light for my consulting work ‚Äì I‚Äôm obsessed with being useful not just right. I‚Äôve always rejected the fancy presentation in favor of the next most useful thing, and I simply took my eye off the ball with this one. I‚Äôm not even sure the client views this project as a real disappointment, there was still some value in it, but I‚Äôm mad at myself personally for this one. A good reminder not to take your eye off the ball. And to push your clients beyond what they tell you the right answer is.

@tomcritchlow https://tomcritchlow.com/2022/11/10/8-years-on-the-road/

This reminds me about Donald Winnicott‚Äôs notion of ‚Äògood enough mother‚Äô.

Winnicott thought that the ‚Äúgood enough mother‚Äù starts out with an almost complete adaptation to her baby‚Äôs needs. She is entirely devoted to the baby and quickly sees to his every need. She sacrifices her own sleep and her own needs to fulfill the needs of her infant.

As time goes by, however, the mother allows the infant to experience small amounts of frustration. She is empathetic and caring but does not immediately rush to the baby‚Äôs every cry. Of course, at first the time-limit to this frustration must be very short. She may allow the baby to cry for a few minutes before her nighttime feeding, but only for a few minutes. She is not ‚Äúperfect‚Äù but she is ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù in that the child only feels a slight amount of frustration.

@PsychToday https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/suffer-the-children/201605/what-is-good-enough-mother

So often when developing ideas, it can be easy to get caught up with the ideal, rather than coming up with an idea that responds to the situation at hand.

name: The Problem with Teaching Sophisticated Vocabulary

content.html:
Alex Quigley shares some activities to support students with making apt vocabulary choices, including:
  • ‚ÄòVocabulary 7-up‚Äô is a simple vocabulary game that encourages pupils to record as many synonyms as they can for common words (seven ideally!).
  • ‚ÄòWord Triplets‚Äô offers students three words to choose from, or synonyms, so that we can begin to shape their apt vocabulary selections.
  • ‚ÄòSaid is dead‚Äô. The use of ‚Äòsaid‚Äô is part of the fabric of academic writing.
  • ‚ÄòSimple >< Sophisticated‚Äô. Teachers can quickly and repeatedly model apt word choices, along with the movement from simple to sophisticated, and the reverse when it is needed.
  • Word gradients. A common approach is to have pupils discuss and select from a range of word choices ‚Äì debating their meaning and value for a given task.
content.value:
Alex Quigley shares some activities to support students with making apt vocabulary choices, including:

‚ÄòVocabulary 7-up‚Äô is a simple vocabulary game that encourages pupils to record as many synonyms as they can for common words (seven ideally!).
‚ÄòWord Triplets‚Äô offers students three words to choose from, or synonyms, so that we can begin to shape their apt vocabulary selections.
‚ÄòSaid is dead‚Äô. The use of ‚Äòsaid‚Äô is part of the fabric of academic writing.
‚ÄòSimple >< Sophisticated‚Äô. Teachers can quickly and repeatedly model apt word choices, along with the movement from simple to sophisticated, and the reverse when it is needed.
Word gradients. A common approach is to have pupils discuss and select from a range of word choices ‚Äì debating their meaning and value for a given task.

summary.html: I am interested here as someone who realizes how much a) community, b) professional learning, and especially c) knowledge production arose from the particular context (including technological, political, personal, epidemiological, generational factors, etc) of 2005 to 2015. And I‚Äôm wondering where teachers‚Äìespecially new teachers‚Äìwill get that next.

content.html: With the changes to Twitter, Dan Meyer wonders where people might go to in order to engage with community now? He suggests that platforms like TikTok do not allow for the same level of engagement. This has me thinking about Dron and Anderson‚Äôs Teaching Crowds and Ian Guest‚Äôs research into Twitter. For Miguel Guhlin, the answer is Mastodon. He has published a number of posts to help with the transition.

name: Wikipedia is swimming in money‚Äîwhy is it begging people to donate?

summary.html: The Wikimedia Foundation (WMF), the non-profit that owns Wikipedia and other volunteer-written websites, is about to reach its 10-year goal of creating a $100 million endowment five years earlier than it planned. Its total funds, which have risen by about $200 million over the past five years, now stand at around $300 million. Its revenue has risen every year. In just the first nine months of its current financial year, it has raked in $142 million in donations according to an internal document‚Äîand already obliterated its previous annual record.

summary.html: Actual Life 3 (January 1 ‚Äì September 9 2022) is the third album from British producer Fred Gibson under the stage name Fred Again. It was released on October 28, 2022, through Atlantic Records.[6] Similar to the previous two releases in the Actual Life series, Actual Life 3 incorporates samples and audio clips from existing material, such as Instagram videos.[7]
summary.value: Actual Life 3 (January 1 ‚Äì September 9 2022) is the third album from British producer Fred Gibson under the stage name Fred Again. It was released on October 28, 2022, through Atlantic Records.[6] Similar to the previous two releases in the Actual Life series, Actual Life 3 incorporates samples and audio clips from existing material, such as Instagram videos.[7]

content.html: I stumbled upon Fred Again last year. I was fascinated in the use of seemingly real-life samples to capture the world. What was interesting is the way in which Fred Gibson continually captures video of his experiences and how he incorporates this into his performances. I loved his use of his Maschine. This desire to move away from the dependency on the computer reminded me of James Blake‚Äôs focus on hardware when playing live. See his short demonstration for Zane Lowe for example. Yet at the same time this ability is balanced with a deep knowledge of music. Listening to his interview with Jamie Lidell, I was left wondering how one falls in with Brian Eno?

This desire to move away from the dependency on the computer reminded me of James Blake‚Äôs focus on hardware when playing live. See his short demonstration for Zane Lowe for example. Yet at the same time this ability is balanced with a deep knowledge of music. Listening to his interview with Jamie Lidell, I was left wondering how one falls in with Brian Eno?

summary.html: Alpha Zulu is the seventh studio album by French indie pop band Phoenix, released on 4 November 2022 through Loyaut√© and Glassnote Records.[3] Self-produced by the band, it is their first album since 2017‚Äôs Ti Amo. The singles ‚ÄúIdentical‚Äù, ‚ÄúAlpha Zulu‚Äù, ‚ÄúTonight‚Äù, and ‚ÄúWinter Solstice‚Äù preceded the album.[4] The band embarked on a North American tour in support of the album, which will visit the UK and Europe in October and November 2022.[5] The album received critical acclaim.
summary.value: Alpha Zulu is the seventh studio album by French indie pop band Phoenix, released on 4 November 2022 through Loyaut√© and Glassnote Records.[3] Self-produced by the band, it is their first album since 2017‚Äôs Ti Amo. The singles ‚ÄúIdentical‚Äù, ‚ÄúAlpha Zulu‚Äù, ‚ÄúTonight‚Äù, and ‚ÄúWinter Solstice‚Äù preceded the album.[4] The band embarked on a North American tour in support of the album, which will visit the UK and Europe in October and November 2022.[5] The album received critical acclaim.

content.html:
For me, Alpha Zulu is a feel good album. I often find myself putting it on in the background when doing this and that:

In a continuation of the direction Phoenix took on their previous two albums, Bankrupt! and Ti Amo, the band favors needling synths and skittering drum machines over the crisp guitars and live percussion of their earlier efforts. Guitars still tinker in the background in spots across Alpha Zulu, and they finally take center stage on both ‚ÄúArtefact‚Äù and the penultimate track, ‚ÄúMy Elixir,‚Äù but the instrument‚Äôs usage almost feels antiquated after the more contemporary, computer-effect-dominated songs that precede them.

Charles Lyons-Burt https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/phoenix-alpha-zulu-album-review/

I also love the film clip for Alpha Zulu and the manipulation of art pieces.

name: American IV: The Man Comes Around Turns 20

summary.html: The American recordings are a slightly misleading legacy. Johnny Cash wasn‚Äôt the mythic poet of darkness that those Rick Rubin records made him out to be ‚Äî or, rather, he wasn‚Äôt just that. Cash was an entertainer. He could be funny and pious and corny. For decades, Cash thrived within the Nashville studio system; he was never an outsider artist. But those American records, American IV in particular, tapped into something powerful and primal about Johnny Cash‚Äôs voice and presence. They gave him a different kind of life. And that dark-specter version of Cash might be the one that people remember best today. Maybe that‚Äôs not fair to Johnny Cash, but Johnny Cash doesn‚Äôt care. He‚Äôs dead, and his legacy was secure long before American IV. In some of his last months on earth, Cash gave the world a profound meditation on loss and mortality, and even if the album only captures one side of Cash, that one side is heavier than heaven.
summary.value: The American recordings are a slightly misleading legacy. Johnny Cash wasn‚Äôt the mythic poet of darkness that those Rick Rubin records made him out to be ‚Äî or, rather, he wasn‚Äôt just that. Cash was an entertainer. He could be funny and pious and corny. For decades, Cash thrived within the Nashville studio system; he was never an outsider artist. But those American records, American IV in particular, tapped into something powerful and primal about Johnny Cash‚Äôs voice and presence. They gave him a different kind of life. And that dark-specter version of Cash might be the one that people remember best today. Maybe that‚Äôs not fair to Johnny Cash, but Johnny Cash doesn‚Äôt care. He‚Äôs dead, and his legacy was secure long before American IV. In some of his last months on earth, Cash gave the world a profound meditation on loss and mortality, and even if the album only captures one side of Cash, that one side is heavier than heaven.

content.html:
There are some covers which are about the original artists, while other covers make the song anew. Cash‚Äôs American Recordings provide a new take on tracks like Mercy Seat, Rusty Cage, Personal Jesus and Hurt. I also love how Rick Ruben focused on creating the right conditions for Cash.

On the other side of such covers is how the original artists appreciated the covers. I find Trent Reznor‚Äôs response pretty funny:

When Reznor first heard Cash‚Äôs version, he still wasn‚Äôt sure what to think: ‚ÄúIt felt like I was watching my girlfriend fuck somebody else.‚Äù (Trent Reznor isn‚Äôt always articulate.) But when Reznor saw Mark Romanek‚Äôs video for Cash‚Äôs ‚ÄúHurt,‚Äù he immediately understood that ‚ÄúHurt‚Äù now belonged to someone else.

@stereogum https://www.stereogum.com/2204405/johnny-cash-hurt-american-iv-the-man-comes-around/reviews/the-anniversary/

But when Reznor saw Mark Romanek‚Äôs video for Cash‚Äôs ‚ÄúHurt,‚Äù he immediately understood that ‚ÄúHurt‚Äù now belonged to someone else.

summary.html: Why do we post messages with text, images, and video online? Do we do it for attention? Do we do it to help educate and inform others? There are many positive and not so positive reasons we post messages online. I do not think many people publish text, images, or video online without intending to influence and communicate with one or many other human beings. I do it to get my ideas out of my head. I do it because I like crafting stories, and having a real or perceived audience helps with this process.
summary.value: Why do we post messages with text, images, and video online? Do we do it for attention? Do we do it to help educate and inform others? There are many positive and not so positive reasons we post messages online. I do not think many people publish text, images, or video online without intending to influence and communicate with one or many other human beings. I do it to get my ideas out of my head. I do it because I like crafting stories, and having a real or perceived audience helps with this process.

content.html: My choice to change my habits in regards to social media and sharing has really led me to reflect why I do what I do. What I have come to realise is that at the heart of it, I share in my own space for me. With this in mind, I like your point about ‚Äògetting things out of your head‚Äô.
content.value: My choice to change my habits in regards to social media and sharing has really led me to reflect why I do what I do. What I have come to realise is that at the heart of it, I share in my own space for me. With this in mind, I like your point about ‚Äògetting things out of your head‚Äô.

content.html:
I was listening to The J Files on Cocteau Twins the other day and Robin Guthrie spoke about the influence of The Birthday Party. They played a few gigs together and were a part of getting them a start with 4AD. The Go-Betweens were similar in that vein. Although it can be easy to go looking for associations and inspiration, what seems at play at the time is the punk ethos.

There are two things that stand out for me about The Go-Betweens second album Before Hollywood. Firstly, the addition of the piano and organ to there sound. I think it is significant that the organ comes in early in the opening track A Bad Debt Follows You. This sets the tone for me for the rest of the album.

The second thing was the contrast in intensity throughout the tracks. One minute there is an urgency, then there is not. Even with this though, there is always a hook pulling you back in.

In a review from the time, Clinton Walker argues that Before Hollywood is a ‚Äòmore complete‚Äô album.

Where Send Me a Lullaby was fragile and occasionally faltering, yet still possessed of an uplifting resonance, Before Hollywood is a more complete album. Endearing as their vulnerability was, the Go-Betweens now play with confidence and solidity, though still with an edge . . . [here] they offer ten deceptively simple pop songs that pack an emotional impact just below a skin of finely wrought and realised melody and rhythmic attack.Page 209

https://www.clintonwalker.com.au/stranded.html

It was interesting listening to this album as I grew up watching Cattle and Cane on Rage late at night, but did not really know any of the other tracks. On Cattle and Cane, I love the story about how McLellan used Nick Cave‚Äôs guitar and stole it‚Äôs only tune:

The album‚Äôs centrepiece, Grant‚Äôs ‚ÄòCattle & Cane‚Äô, was a song born of a certain homesickness/nostalgia, and written on a guitar owned by Nick Cave. ‚ÄòSo that‚Äôs why I could never write anything on it,‚Äô Nick later complained. ‚ÄòDid I steal its only tune?‚Äô Grant apologised. ‚ÄòI‚Äôll give you a credit next time I see my publisher.‚Äô Page 180

https://www.clintonwalker.com.au/stranded.html
content.value:

I think it is significant that the organ comes in early in the opening track A Bad Debt Follows You. This sets the tone for me for the rest of the album.
The second thing was the contrast in intensity throughout the tracks. One minute there is an urgency, then there is not. Even with this though, there is always a hook pulling you back in.

Where Send Me a Lullaby was fragile and occasionally faltering, yet still possessed of an uplifting resonance, Before Hollywood is a more complete album. Endearing as their vulnerability was, the Go-Betweens now play with confidence and solidity, though still with an edge . . . [here] they offer ten deceptively simple pop songs that pack an emotional impact just below a skin of finely wrought and realised melody and rhythmic attack.Page 209

summary.html: Each week I write a love letter to the Internet. You can subscribe here. Spoiler alert!!! It‚Äôs not all good.
summary.value: Each week I write a love letter to the Internet. You can subscribe here. Spoiler alert!!! It‚Äôs not all good.

content.html: I really like your description of your newsletters as a ‚Äòlove letter to the internet‚Äô. I am not exactly sure what description I would give to mine. It sometimes feels like a habit without purpose at times.
content.value: I really like your description of your newsletters as a ‚Äòlove letter to the internet‚Äô. I am not exactly sure what description I would give to mine. It sometimes feels like a habit without purpose at times.

name: #FeedReaderFriday: A Suggestion for Changing our Social Media Patterns

summary.html: In the recent Twitter Migration, in addition to trying out Mastodon, I‚Äôve been seeing some people go back to blogs or platforms like Micro.blog, WordPress, Tumblr, WriteFreely (like Mastodon it‚Äôs a part of the Fediverse, but built for blogging instead of short posts) and variety of others. They?‚Ä¶

They?‚Ä¶

content.html: Sorry, late to getting to this piece Chris, as I get to my feeds in my own time. I have long lived a feed first existence. Even when engaging with Twitter, I have been consuming via my feed reader. I just realised that I can also produce a feed for Mastodon too using Granary.io. I sometimes feel like I am late to the conversation, however on the flip side I feel that the conversation is more in hand. I feel that if it is worth having then waiting is fine.

summary.html: Upon visiting the site‚Äîwhich is unaffiliated with either person‚Äîyou‚Äôll see AI-generated charcoal portraits of the two men in profile. Between them, a transcript of AI-generated text is highlighted in yellow as AI-generated voices simulating those of Herzog or ≈Ωi≈æek read through it. The conversation goes back and forth between them, complete with distinct accents, and you can skip between each segment by clicking the arrows beneath the portraits.
